qas.question: What was traditionally believed to be absorbed quickly causing blood - glucose levels to rapidly rise?
What is an example of a simple carbohydrate?
When simple carbohydrates undergo metabolic pathways, what do they result in after partial catabolism?
What is glucose able to stimulate that is required in the human body?
Where are beta cells that attach to insulin located?

context: Traditionally, <a0_0>simple carbohydrates<a0_0/> are believed to be absorbed quickly, and therefore to raise blood-glucose levels more rapidly than complex carbohydrates. This, however, is not accurate. Some simple carbohydrates (e.g., <a1_0>fructose<a1_0/>) follow different metabolic pathways (e.g., fructolysis) that result in only a partial catabolism to <a2_0>glucose<a2_0/>, while, in essence, many complex carbohydrates may be digested at the same rate as simple carbohydrates. Glucose stimulates the <a3_0>production of insulin<a3_0/> through food entering the bloodstream, which is grasped by the beta cells in the <a4_0>pancreas<a4_0/>.
